thread.title: SIMMONS: Estrada shows his worth to Blue Jays
thread.title_full: SIMMONS: Estrada shows his worth to Blue Jays

title: SIMMONS: Estrada shows his worth to Blue Jays
text:
Report an error ARLINGTON, TEXAS - 
When Marco Estrada walked to the mound Sunday night, there was so much unknown, about him, about what’s left or not left of this Blue Jays playoff season, about the future, immediate and otherwise. 
So much surrounding a pitcher of little pedigree, who preceded this Blue Jays team to greatness by a month or two. He came from almost nowhere — OK, Milwaukee — to do what he had never done before, before his teammates lined up and began operating the same way. In this season and again Sunday night. 
And now questions and short-term celebration. Until Monday afternoon. Questions about this series. About this Blue Jays roster. About what to think today and what to think tomorrow. And in particular, a question that hasn’t been central all that often but seems central today: Will Estrada be a Blue Jay next season? 
Was his dominant start Sunday night the last of this Jays historic season or in Estrada’s case, the last of his one and only season in Toronto? The theme at the oddly named Globe Life Park was all about beginnings and endings, about one more chance or no more chances for the Jays. Such was the tension on a Texas Sunday night. So much on the line. A season that exploded into so much more and the giant buildup of the past 10 weeks on the brink. Estrada so on his game Sunday; the Blue Jays daringly leaving too many opportunities behind. 
This is what this confounding playoff season has come to for this Blue Jays team after losing the first two playoff games at home. They remain on a tightrope, wobbly slightly There is no wiggle room. They fall and they’re finished. They tripped a little in Game 3 before turning it one-sided. By late this afternoon, this series is heading to Game 5 or it’s over. 
Chris Colabello talked about this Blue Jays team before the game, about how close this team is, about how tight everybody is and how much they believe in each other. He called this the greatest experience of his baseball life. That was before Troy Tulowitzki’s stunning sixth inning home run meant there would be a Game 4. 
“We have to win three games,” said Colabello. “But you can’t do that in one night. You have to win the first one. Then worry about the second one. And go from there.” 
For Estrada, this is a finality of sorts that is strictly personal. He is a free agent at the end of this unlikely season. He hasn’t exactly, by baseball’s standards, cashed in on his up and down career. David Price made more money in half a season that Estrada has made in his entire career. 
But this has been his season in the sun: Early on, in June, he won a game in Washington against Max Scherzer that may have prevented a firing or two or discussion about it. That seems so long ago now. He won then, continued to win, was sharp as he can be on a hot Sunday night. 
He did what he had to do. What the Blue Jays, who want to keep him, needed. He has said on occasion that he would like to stay in Toronto. But the price is going up and free agency tends to take on a life of its own. It will cost in the range of three seasons and $27 million to retain Estrada. 
In David Price’s 11 starts with the Blue Jays, the Jays won nine of those games, his earned run average was 2.31. In the 13 starts Estrada made from the time Price came to Toronto, the Jays were 9-4 and Estrada had a 2.52 earned run average. In the one playoff starts, Estrada outshone Price, who was warming in the bullpen late Sunday. 
Price will command some $200 million in free agency, and demand for him will be rich. Estrada is two years older. Demand for him will be growing. By how much it’s impossible to know. 
While trying to balance what this series is with thinking about what this team will next season, the Jays realize some will certainly be gone. Estrada’s future is up in the air, Mark Buehrle won’t be here and who knows what the next evolution of Drew Hutchison will bring. That leaves Marcus Stroman and R.A. Dickey and who knows what else. 
It makes Estrada more valuable to the Jays than maybe anything else. And they sure owe him a little something for keeping this series alive, throwing 61/3 innings and just one run allowed. He didn’t give up a run or have any difficulty until the seventh inning. 
“He’s the total package,” Dickey said of Estrada. “I said it in spring training, in order to win a championship, any championship, a division, an AL championship, a world championship, you’re going to have to have guys step up ... I mean he was as close to a cut in spring training and here he is probably one of our top two starters. 
“Marco has proven to be an incredible asset for us.” 
He played the part of saviour in June at a time when the Blue Jays had lost seven games more than they had won. He stopped the bleeding then, did it again when it was mandatory Sunday night. There was no margin for error and on a night when that was necessary, Marco Estrada provided none. Sponsored Links
